Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Precise Assembly and Evaluation of Sequence-Defined Macromolecular Architectures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sequence-defined oligomers are short polymers with chemical and biological properties that can be dictated by controlling the composition and relative arrangement of the building blocks. Motivated by their potential applications in biological systems, such as therapeutics, Prof. Alabi of Cornell University develops novel approaches to the synthesis of sequence-defined polymers and investigates how the composition and sequence affect their properties. Educational and outreach activities are integrated throughout the duration of this research project through a common theme that is focused promoting peer-to-peer learning and empowering young aspiring scientists to take up leadership positions in communicating science ideas to the broader public. Based on the Dr. Alabi's experience creating a comprehensive 3-day workshop for underrepresented high school students, this project develops an "Ambassador Program" that involves teaching and supporting high school students how to disseminate ideas in science and engineering to their peers and the broader public.

Building on the method invented by the Alabi group for the synthesis of sequence-defined linear oligothioetheramides (oligoTEAs) that undergo pre-programmed self-assembly into desired 3D architectures, this research project aims to further develop novel, efficient methods for the synthesis of sequence-defined multicyclic structures. Towards this challenging goal, this research investigates how molecular composition and sequence influence chain dynamics, the efficiency of macrocyclization, and ultimately the properties of the macromolecular assemblies. In addition to providing research training to graduate and undergraduate students, an "Ambassador Program" is being developed to train and equip high school students with the leadership and communication skills required to disseminate topics in science and engineering to their peers and the broader public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This ongoing search for new materials with advanced properties has fueled research interests into the synthesis of new polymer architectures that can be easily synthesized, tuned and made at scale. While much of the focus in the last two decades has been devoted to achieving precise control over polymer chain length, few studies have investigated methods for the synthesis of polymers with well-defined sequences.

Our goal of this CAREER proposal was to precisely control the sequence and structure of synthetic macromolecules towards the assembly of active biological ligands from a set of simple monomeric building blocks (Figure 1). We successfully developed a method for the assembly of sequence-defined oligothioetheramides (oligoTEAs) and thoroughly characterized their phyicochemical, structural and biological properties. As new structural class, oligoTEAs are uniquely suited to study and control macromolecular structure and chain dynamics due to their interchangeable pendant and backbone groups. Moreover, their abiotic backbone renders them resistant to proteolysis and should result in longer bioavailability. The chemical versatility of oligoTEAs surpasses other peptidomimetics and allows their physical and chemical properties to be finely tuned and quantified. Additional benefits that set oligoTEAs apart from other peptidomimetics include rapid synthetic assembly with precise sequence-control, relatively inexpensive production costs, a straightforward two-step monomer synthesis, and a massive scope of chemically diverse monomers.

We accomplished a number of goals, including investigating the relationship between sequence, structure/macromolecular properties and biological function. We explored solution-phase characterization methods such as pulse-field gradient (PFG) NMR experiments to measure macromolecular hydrodynamic radius, electron spin resonance (ESR) to measure end-to-end distance, and MD simulations to visualize the time evolution and configurational space of the oligomer. Parameters obtained from these experiments were fed into the Stokes-Einstein-Sutherland (SES) diffusion theory with size and shape models to quantify size and aspect ratio?s with simple geometries. Our results highlighted how entropic and hydrophobic driving forces can facilitate ?collapse? of flexible structures. While low resolution, these characterization techniques provided insight into the ensemble of highly flexible macromolecules.

We also evaluated the relationship between the structure of oligoTEAs and their antimicrobial activities. Using our novel oligoTEA platform, we developed a new class of cationic oligoTEAs with promising bactericidal activity in the presence of elevated salt and serum proteins against a variety of Gram-positive and Gram-negative pathogens . We also performed a wide range of sequence/composition-activity studies to investigate the effect of architecture, oligomer length and backbone composition, type of cationic group, and the backbone hydrophobic sequence. Overall, oligoTEAs with pendant guanidinium groups looked the most promising with selectivity values in the 20-100-fold range. Mechanistic studies confirmed the primary mode of killing to be via membrane disruption. These results illustrate the potential of oligoTEAs to serve as effective antimicrobial agents. To understand their precise mechanism of action, we used results from biophysical experiments to derive a de novo kinetic framework that was validated by modeling oligomer-membrane interactions as observed by sensitive surface plasmon resonance (SPR). The proposed model and its set of differential equations was fit to the experimental responses observed by SPR with great success. Model fits of the SPR data across all concentrations correlate the irreversible aggregate formation with biological activity. Furthermore, application of this model to other oligoTEA kinetic data in our collection gave a good correlation across the board between aggregate formation and antibacterial activity. In the quest to develop new antibiotics, our results highlight multimeric lipid aggregation as a new, independent biophysical parameter for further design and optimization of membrane-targeting antimicrobials. 

Finally, we reviewed the critical reaction that makes the assembly of oligoTEAs possible, i.e. the thiol-Michael addition. We combined experimental and quantum mechanical modeling approaches using density functional theory (DFT) to examine the thiol-Michael reaction of N-allyl-N-acrylamide monomers used to prepare sequence-defined oligoTEAs. During our investigation, we discovered a previously unconsidered step that we termed ?product decomplexation?, which occurs as the product physically dissociates from other co-reactants after chain transfer. All monomers in our study, capturing a range of functional groups, supported this finding. Hydrogen-bonding between reactants increased the activation energy emphasizing the rate-limitation of the product decomplexation. These new findings describe a new structure-kinetic relationship for thiol-Michael acceptors to enable further design of reactive monomers for synthetic polymers. 

Overall, our work in during this CAREER period has led to the development of a new class of sequence-defined polymers, new methods for their solution phase characterization, structure activity relationships to guide their use as antimicrobial agents, and mechanistic investigations into the fundamental reaction required for oligoTEA assembly, i.e. the thiol-Michael addtion. The body of work generated should of benefit to the chemists and polymeric scientists working toward the assembly of precise polymers for a wide range of applications.
